content.html:
Pluralistic: Web apps could de-monopolize mobile devices (13 Dec 2022) ‚Äì Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

But you can‚Äôt have a web app without a web-app-compatible browser, and you can‚Äôt get a web-app-compatible browser in Apple‚Äôs App Store. The only browsers permitted in the App Store are those based on WebKit, the browser engine behind Safari. This means that every browser on iOS, from Firefox to Edge to Chrome, is just a reskinned version of Safari.

content.html:
Writing Is Magic - Marc‚Äôs Blog

I find, more often than not, that I understand something much less well when I sit down to write about it than when I‚Äôm thinking about it in the shower. In fact, I find that I change my own mind on things a lot when I try write them down. It really is a powerful tool for finding clarity in your own mind. Once you have clarity in your own mind, you‚Äôre much more able to explain it to others.
content.value:

content.html:
Derek Powazek - A community isn‚Äôt a garden, it‚Äôs a bar.

The first thirty years of the web may have been an orgy of unregulated expansion, but that era is over. The EU has been a leader with the GDPR, but there‚Äôs more coming. And I‚Äôm glad. The big players have had plenty of time to get their shit together and they haven‚Äôt. It‚Äôs time to regulate them as much as we regulate a shot of bourbon.

content.html:
A year of new avenues

All along, from the frothy 1990s to the per¬≠co¬≠lat¬≠ing 2000s to the frozen 2010s to today, the web has been the sure thing. All along, it‚Äôs been grow¬≠ing and maturing, sprout¬≠ing new capabilities. From my van¬≠tage point, that growth has seemed to accel¬≠er¬≠ate in the past five years; CSS, in par¬≠tic¬≠u¬≠lar, has become incred¬≠i¬≠bly flex¬≠i¬≠ble and expressive. Maybe even a bit overstuffed‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut I‚Äôll take¬†it.

For peo¬≠ple who care about cre¬≠at¬≠ing worlds together, rather than get¬≠ting rich, the web is the past and the web is the future. What luck, that this decentralized, per¬≠mis¬≠sion¬≠less sys¬≠tem claimed a posi¬≠tion at the heart of the inter¬≠net, and stuck there. It‚Äôs limited, of course; frustrating; some¬≠times maddening. But that‚Äôs every cre¬≠ative medium. That‚Äôs¬†life.

content.html:
I decided to listen to what the universe was trying to tell me.

Turns out the universe is mostly just sick and tired of being anthropomorphised.

content.html:
My upcoming appearance at An Event Apart next week to talk about declarative design isn‚Äôt the only upcoming trip to San Francisco in my calendar.

Two months from today I‚Äôll be back in San Francisco for Leading Design. It‚Äôs on February 7th and 8th.

This event is long overdue. We‚Äôve never had Leading Design in San Francisco before, but we were all set to go ahead with the inaugural SF gathering ‚Ä¶in March 2020. We all know what happened next.

So this event will be three years in the making.

Rebacca is doing amazing work, as usual, putting together a fantastic line-up of speakers:

They‚Äôll be sharing their insights, their stories and their ideas ‚Äî as well as some of their pain from past challenges. It‚Äôs all designed to help you navigate your own leadership journey.

I‚Äôll be there to MC the event, which is a great honour for me. And I reckon I‚Äôll be up to the challenge, having just done the double whammy of hosting Leading Design London and Clarity back-to-back.

I would love to see you in San Francisco! If you‚Äôve attended a Leading Design event before, then you know how transformational it can be. If you haven‚Äôt, then now is your chance.

Early bird tickets are still available until mid December, so if you‚Äôre thinking about coming, I suggest making that decision now.

If you know anyone in the bay area who‚Äôs in a design leadership position, be sure to tell them about Leading Design San Francisco‚Äîthey don‚Äôt want to miss this!
